Mount an entire state somewhere https://github.com/ubuntu/zsys/issues/151

It can be very useful to browse the data in zfs snapshots. Snapshots can be browsed from the .zfs directory in the root of any dataset (where zfs will automount them for you on access), and you can mount them manually as well. The typical Ubuntu zfs installation has a lot of datasets though, which quite fragments things. These exist for good reasons, but it becomes difficult to (for example) browse a coherent view of a specific state, as the state is spread over many datasets. It would be useful if zsys can be asked to mount an entire state under some directory. This would mount the correct snapshot of each dataset involved in the state at the correct location, reproducing the entire file system (or at least that which is under zsys control) in the target directory. Zfs itself can't do this as it does not have a coherent view of what snapshots belong together, but zsys knows exactly which snapshots make up a state. One interesting use case for this feature is to make a system state save, mount it somewhere, and then have any regular backup utility (which knows nothing about zfs) back it up. This ensures that the backup is atomic, and asking zsysctl to make and then mount a state save can easily be done from a pre-backup hook or with a script (and the post-backup hook would unmount and then delete the save, of course)."

Unfortunately, as the history is non linear, there is no easy way to include real snapshot disk usage by snapshots (even upstream ZFS doesn’t have any facilities to that because it’s complex): the real take is "you should combine snapshots to free space, not only one". If you look at the USE size of a snapshots, you will indeed see very little space that can be taken by only removing on snapshot, as most of the space is common between multiple of them. So, it’s not an individual snapshots that need to take into account, but a range (including its dependencies). This command should analyze the best strategy to reclaim spaces by deleting states: - it should analyzes multiple sets and combination of snapshots and their dependencies - it should start from the bigger space winner (writing area difference from current filesystem dataset) by looking at what was allocated when and what is out of date to current - it should give easy zsysctl state remove command line for people to reclaim the state. This should be done by bo ing with times (and include any dependencies, even if outside of this time range)."
